docs.title: Welcome to the Sandbox
docs.text: This is where we experiment with MkDocs features, configurations, and more.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
• Setup
  • Plugins

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
• Markdown

:smiley: :thumbsup: :tada:

docs.title: Markdown Quick Reference
docs.text:
Below is a single Markdown document that demonstrates many common Markdown features. You can copy this into a file named Markdown.md. Feel free to add or remove sections based on your needs!

This document highlights the most common Markdown syntax and features. Simply copy and paste this into a .md file to have a quick reference.

docs.title: 1. Headings
docs.text:
Use # through ###### to create headings of different levels.

# Heading 1
## Heading 2
### Heading 3
#### Heading 4
##### Heading 5
###### Heading 6

docs.title: 2.1 Emphasis
docs.text:
• Italic (using asterisks) markdown *Italic*

  • Italic (using underscores) markdown _Italic_

  • Bold (using double asterisks) markdown **Bold**

  • Bold (using double underscores) markdown __Bold__

  • Bold and Italic markdown ***Bold and Italic***

  • Bold and Italic markdown ___Bold and Italic___

docs.title: 2.2 Strikethrough
docs.text: • ~~Strikethrough~~ markdown ~~Strikethrough~~

docs.title: 3. Paragraphs and Line Breaks
docs.text:
Simply write your text in separate lines for paragraphs:

This is the first paragraph.

This is the second paragraph.

To force a line break, end a line with two or more spaces:

This line ends with two spaces.  
So this text starts on a new line.

docs.title: 4. Blockquotes
docs.text:
Use > to create blockquotes. They can be nested by using multiple > characters.

> This is a blockquote.

> > Nested blockquote.

This is a blockquote.

Nested blockquote.

docs.title: 5.1 Unordered Lists
docs.text:
Use -, +, or * followed by a space to create unordered lists.

- Item 1
- Item 2
  - Nested Item 2.1
  - Nested Item 2.2
- Item 3
  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  • Nested Item 2.1
  • Nested Item 2.2
  • Item 3

docs.title: 5.2 Ordered Lists
docs.text:
Use numbers followed by a period (1., 2., 3.) to create ordered lists.

1. First item
2. Second item
3. Third item
   1. Sub item
   2. Sub item
  1. First item
  2. Second item
  3. Third item
  4. Sub item
  5. Sub item

docs.title: 6. Horizontal Rules
docs.text:
Use three or more asterisks (***), dashes (---), or underscores (___) on their own line.

---
***
___

docs.title: 7.1 Inline Links
docs.text:
[This is a link](https://www.example.com)

This is a link

docs.title: 7.2 Reference Links
docs.text:
[Reference-style link][example-ref]

[example-ref]: https://www.example.com "Optional Title"

Reference-style link

docs.title: 8.1 Inline Images
docs.text: ![Markdown Logo](https://markdown-here.com/img/icon256.png)

docs.title: 8.2 Reference Style Images
docs.text:
![Alt text][img-ref]

[img-ref]: https://markdown-here.com/img/icon256.png "Markdown Logo"

docs.title: 9.1 Inline Code
docs.text:
Surround inline code with backticks:

Use the `printf()` function to print to standard output.

Example: Use the printf() function to print to standard output.

docs.title: 9.2 Code Blocks
docs.text:
Use triple backticks (```) with an optional language identifier for syntax highlighting:

Example in Markdown ```markdown ```python def hello_world(): print("Hello, world!") ``` ```

Which renders as:

def hello_world():
    print("Hello, world!")

docs.title: 10. Tables
docs.text:
Use | to create tables. You can align columns using colons (:).

| Left Align | Center Align | Right Align |
|:-----------|:------------:|------------:|
| Item A     |   Item B     |       Item C|
| Item D     |   Item E     |       Item F|
Left Align Center Align Right Align Item A Item B Item C Item D Item E Item F

docs.title: 11. Footnotes
docs.text:
Use [^1] syntax to add footnotes.

Here is a sentence with a footnote.[^1]

[^1]: This is the footnote text.

Here is a sentence with a footnote.1

docs.title: 12. Task Lists (GitHub Flavored Markdown)
docs.text:
You can create checklists using - [ ] or - [x].

- [x] Completed task
- [ ] Incomplete task
- [ ] Another task
  • [x] Completed task
  • [ ] Incomplete task
  • [ ] Another task

docs.title: 13. Emojis (GitHub / Some Editors)
docs.text:
You can use :emoji_name: to insert emojis (in some Markdown renderers like GitHub).

For example:

:smiley: :thumbsup: :tada:

:smiley: :thumbsup: :tada:

docs.title: 14. HTML in Markdown
docs.text:
You can mix HTML for more complex layouts:

<p style="color: blue;">This is a blue paragraph in HTML.</p>

This is a blue paragraph in HTML.

docs.title: 15. Escaping Characters
docs.text:
Use a backslash to escape Markdown characters if needed:

\*This text is not italicized.\*

*This text is not italicized.*

docs.title: 16. Collapsible Sections (GitHub Flavored Markdown)
That’s It!
docs.text:
This cheat sheet should cover the most commonly used Markdown syntax. Experiment, mix and match, and enjoy writing clean and visually appealing documentation!

Feel free to modify this document in any way you see fit. Happy writing!

  1. This is the footnote text. ↩

docs.title: Setup
docs.text: Instructions on how to install and configure this MkDocs project.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Install Python 3.
  2. pip install mkdocs-material
  3. mkdocs serve to start your local dev server.

  2. pip install mkdocs-material
  3. mkdocs serve to start your local dev server.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Details on configuring mkdocs.yml, including theme, plugins, etc.

docs.title: Dictionary
docs.text: • Best Practice

docs.title: List
docs.text: • List Functions

docs.title: Mistake #1: Wrong way to check if a key exists
docs.text:
Sometimes people do this to check if the key exists or not:

my_dict = {"name": "Kiran", "age": 24}
if "name" in my_dict:
    print(my_dict["name"])
else:
    print("No name found")

A better way to do this:

my_dict = {"name": "Kiran", "age": 24}
print(my_dict.get("name", "No name found"))

This method makes the code cleaner by removing the extra if-else checks.

docs.title: Mistake #2: Incorrect looping over both keys and values
docs.text:
Many people loop like this:

my_dict = {"a": 1, "b": 2, "c": 3}
for key in my_dict:
    print(key, my_dict[key])

A better approach:

for key, value in my_dict.items():
    print(key, value)

This makes the code more readable and efficient.

docs.title: Mistake #3: Incorrect way of merging dictionaries
docs.text:
Some beginners merge dictionaries like this:

dict1 = {"a": 1, "b": 2}
dict2 = {"b": 3, "c": 4}
dict1.update(dict2)
print(dict1)

This modifies dict1 in place. Instead, use dictionary unpacking:

dict1 = {"a": 1, "b": 2}
dict2 = {"b": 3, "c": 4}
new_dict = {**dict1, **dict2}
print(new_dict)  # {'a': 1, 'b': 3, 'c': 4}

This creates a new dictionary, avoiding accidental modifications.

docs.title: Mistake #4: Overusing defaultdict
docs.text:
Example of unnecessary defaultdict usage:

from collections import defaultdict
my_dict = defaultdict(int)
my_dict["a"] += 1  # Works, but is it needed?

A simpler approach:

my_dict = {}
my_dict["a"] = my_dict.get("a", 0) + 1

This avoids unnecessary imports and keeps the code simple.

docs.title: Mistake #5: Ignoring dictionary performance
docs.text:
When dealing with large dictionaries:

my_dict = {i: i**2 for i in range(10_000_000)}

This consumes a lot of memory. Instead, use a generator:

def squared_numbers():
    for i in range(10_000_000):
        yield i, i**2

my_dict = dict(squared_numbers())

This approach reduces memory usage.

docs.title: Mistake #6: Misusing setdefault()
docs.text:
Beginners often do this:

data = {}
if "name" not in data:
    data["name"] = "kiran"

A better way:

data = {}
data.setdefault("name", "kiran")

However, using setdefault() incorrectly can waste time:

name = data.setdefault("name", some_expensive_function())

Even if "name" is present, some_expensive_function() is still executed. Instead, use:

name = data.get("name", "kiran")

docs.title: Mistake #7: Not using Counter for counting
docs.text:
Many beginners count items manually:

words = ["apple", "banana", "apple"]
word_count = {}
for word in words:
    word_count[word] = word_count.get(word, 0) + 1

A better approach using Counter:

from collections import Counter
word_count = Counter(words)

This makes the code cleaner and more efficient.

By following these best practices, your Python dictionary usage will become more efficient and readable!

docs.title: map()
docs.text: numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4] doubled = list(map(lambda x: x * 2, numbers)) print(doubled) # [2, 4, 6, 8]
